items.title: Why there are protests in Iran and what Trump says about US action
items.standfirst: More than 2,400 protesters are reported to have been killed in a violent crackdown by security forces. Here's what you need to know.
items.content: More than 2,400 protesters are reported to have been killed in a violent crackdown by security forces. Here's what you need to know.

items.title: Trump’s Message To Iranian Protesters: ‘Help Is On Its Way’
items.standfirst: By Virginia Allen, The Daily Signal | January 13, 2026 President Donald Trump shared a brief but direct message to protesters in Iran on Tuesday morning. “Iranian Patriots, KEEP PROTESTING – TAKE OVER YOUR INSTITUTIONS!!! Save the names of the killers and abusers. They will pay a big price,”…

items.title: Funerals in Iran for civilians and security forces killed during protests
items.standfirst: Iran has been holding funerals for security force members killed during protests and for civilians killed by ‘rioters’.
items.content: Iran has been holding funerals for security force members killed during protests and for civilians killed by ‘rioters’.

items.title: Iran calls for fast trials of protesters despite Trump’s warning
items.standfirst: Iran's judiciary chief on Wednesday called for fast-track trials for detained protesters, despite US President Donald Trump's threat of "very strong action" if the Islamic republic goes ahead with executions. It came as the verified death toll of people killed in a crackdown on protesters passed the 2,000 mark, according to rights groups based outside Iran. France24 International Affairs editor Kethevane Gorjestani tells us more.
items.content: Iran's judiciary chief on Wednesday called for fast-track trials for detained protesters, despite US President Donald Trump's threat of "very strong action" if the Islamic republic goes ahead with executions. It came as the verified death toll of people killed in a crackdown on protesters passed the 2,000 mark, according to rights groups based outside Iran. France24 International Affairs editor Kethevane Gorjestani tells us more.

items.title: 'Now there's the threat of executions' in Iran
items.standfirst: An Iranian security official says 2,000 people have been killed so far after a crackdown on weeks of anti-government protests.
items.content: An Iranian security official says 2,000 people have been killed so far after a crackdown on weeks of anti-government protests.

items.title: Iranian death toll reaches 2,000, rights group says, as Trump tells protesters 'help is on the way'
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump urged Iranian civilians to keep protesting and said “help is on its way” Tuesday amid a crackdown on anti-government demonstrations that a U.S.-based human rights group says has killed 2,500 people
items.content: President Donald Trump urged Iranian civilians to keep protesting and said “help is on its way” Tuesday amid a crackdown on anti-government demonstrations that a U.S.-based human rights group says has killed 2,500 people

items.title: Crane falls onto moving passenger train in Thailand, killing dozens
items.standfirst: A construction crane fell onto a moving passenger train, causing a fiery derailment that killed at least 30 people and injuring dozens more in northeastern Thailand.
items.content: A construction crane fell onto a moving passenger train, causing a fiery derailment that killed at least 30 people and injuring dozens more in northeastern Thailand.

items.title: Crane crushes parts of train in Thailand, killing at least 30 people, officials say

items.content: A construction crane collapsed onto a moving train in Thailand, killing at least 30 people, officials said. Jonathan Head, with BBC News, a CBS News partner, has more.

items.title: What happened in the deadly Thailand rail accident?
items.standfirst: A Thai passenger train was crushed by construction cranes that slammed onto carriages, killing at least 29 people.
items.content: A Thai passenger train was crushed by construction cranes that slammed onto carriages, killing at least 29 people.

items.title: At least 28 killed as crane collapses on train in Thailand
items.standfirst: Crane in use on high-speed rail project hits passing train, causing it to derailAt least 28 people in Thailand have been killed and scores injured after a crane collapsed on to a passenger train and derailed it, officials said.Footage from the scene verified by Agence France-Presse showed the crane’s broken structure resting on giant concrete pillars and smoke rising from the wreckage of the train below. Continue reading...

items.title: Deadly train accident in Thailand
items.standfirst: At least 30 people were killed when a construction crane collapsed onto a moving train in northeastern Thailand, at the site of a planned high-speed rail project intended to eventually link China with much of Southeast Asia, reports Delano D’Souza.
items.content: At least 30 people were killed when a construction crane collapsed onto a moving train in northeastern Thailand, at the site of a planned high-speed rail project intended to eventually link China with much of Southeast Asia, reports Delano D’Souza.

items.title: At least 32 killed after crane collapses on train in Thailand
items.standfirst: Sixty-four people were left injured, including a one-year-old and an 85-year-old.
items.content: Sixty-four people were left injured, including a one-year-old and an 85-year-old.

items.title: Thailand: At least 29 dead as crane collapses onto train
items.standfirst: At least 29 people were killed in Thailand on Wednesday morning after a crane fell onto a moving train travelling from Bangkok to northeastern Thailand. Authorities say more than 60 people are injured, including a one year old.
items.content: At least 29 people were killed in Thailand on Wednesday morning after a crane fell onto a moving train travelling from Bangkok to northeastern Thailand. Authorities say more than 60 people are injured, including a one year old.

items.title: 'Grim scene': BBC on site after crane collapses on train in Thailand

items.content: Correspondent Jonathan Head says the 'devastating' accident is an enormous setback for Thailand's efforts to modernise its infrastructure.

items.title: France bans 10 British far-right activists for attacking migrant boats
items.standfirst: The French interior ministry on Wednesday banned 10 members of the British far-right "Raise the Colours" group for searching and destroying small migrant boats in the English Channel and conducting propaganda activities. The individuals, who were not named, were prohibited from entering or residing in France.
items.content: The French interior ministry on Wednesday banned 10 members of the British far-right "Raise the Colours" group for searching and destroying small migrant boats in the English Channel and conducting propaganda activities. items.title: ‘Our perspectives continue to differ,’ say Danish and Greenlandic ministers after US meeting – Europe live
items.standfirst: Trump claims only US can protect territory and says ‘two dogsleds won’t do it’ as Danish and Greenlandic ministers hold talks with vice-presidentPeople in Greenland: share your views on Trump’s recent commentsUS president Donald Trump has doubled down on his rhetoric on getting control of Greenland, insisting that the US “needs Greenland for the purpose of national security.”In a social media post, Trump claimed that “Nato should be leading the way for us to get it,” and “if we don’t, Russia or China will, and that is not going to happen!”“Militarily, without the vast power of the United States, much of which I built during my first term, and am now bringing to a new and even higher level, Nato would not be an effective force or deterrent - not even close! They know that, and so do I.” Continue reading...
items.content: Trump claims only US can protect territory and says ‘two dogsleds won’t do it’ as Danish and Greenlandic ministers hold talks with vice-presidentPeople in Greenland: share your views on Trump’s recent commentsUS president Donald Trump has doubled down on his rhetoric on getting control of Greenland, insisting that the US “needs Greenland for the purpose of national security.”In a social media post, Trump claimed that “Nato should be leading the way for us to get it,” and “if we don’t, Russia or China will, and that is not going to happen!”“Militarily, without the vast power of the United States, much of which I built during my first term, and am now bringing to a new and even higher level, Nato would not be an effective force or deterrent - not even close! They know that, and so do I.” Continue reading...

items.title: Watch live: Greenland, Denmark ‘agree to disagree’ with US after White House meeting
items.standfirst: Denmark's Foreign Minister Lars Lokke Rasmussen and Greenland's Foreign Minister Vivian Motzfeldt discuss the outcome of their talks with US Vice President J.D. Vance and Secretary of State Marco Rubio at the White House on Wednesday. Their meeting follows President Donald Trump’s demands that the US take control of Greenland, an autonomous territory of Denmark.
items.content: Denmark's Foreign Minister Lars Lokke Rasmussen and Greenland's Foreign Minister Vivian Motzfeldt discuss the outcome of their talks with US Vice President J.D. Vance and Secretary of State Marco Rubio at the White House on Wednesday. Their meeting follows President Donald Trump’s demands that the US take control of Greenland, an autonomous territory of Denmark.

items.title: US concludes talks with Denmark and Greenland on Trump’s takeover demands
items.standfirst: Danish embassy due to brief journalists on results of negotiations involving JD Vance and Marco RubioEurope live – latest updatesClosely watched talks on Donald Trump’s demands to take over Greenland have ended in Washington after nearly an hour.The vice-president, JD Vance, and secretary of state, Marco Rubio, hosted the foreign ministers of Denmark and Greenland on Wednesday in what observers worried could be an ambush meant to pressure the Danes into ceding the territory under US economic and military pressure. Continue reading...
items.content: Danish embassy due to brief journalists on results of negotiations involving JD Vance and Marco RubioEurope live – latest updatesClosely watched talks on Donald Trump’s demands to take over Greenland have ended in Washington after nearly an hour.The vice-president, JD Vance, and secretary of state, Marco Rubio, hosted the foreign ministers of Denmark and Greenland on Wednesday in what observers worried could be an ambush meant to pressure the Danes into ceding the territory under US economic and military pressure. Continue reading...

items.title: Greenland and Denmark officials meet with Vance and Rubio
items.standfirst: The foreign ministers of Denmark and Greenland met Vice President JD Vance and Secretary of State Marco Rubio amid President Donald Trump's push to take control of the Arctic island. NBC News' Garrett Haake reports on the meeting's outcome and the officials' current stance regarding Greenland.
items.content: The foreign ministers of Denmark and Greenland met Vice President JD Vance and Secretary of State Marco Rubio amid President Donald Trump's push to take control of the Arctic island. NBC News' Garrett Haake reports on the meeting's outcome and the officials' current stance regarding Greenland.

items.title: Greenland: Denmark and Greenland FMs meet Vance, Rubio at White House
items.standfirst: The foreign ministers of Denmark and Greenland are meeting at the White House today after President Donald Trump once again reiterated his desire for the United States to control Greenland, the world’s largest island. In a post on Truth Social earlier today, Trump said that anything short of Greenland being “in the hands” of the US was “unacceptable,” adding that NATO would become “more effective” if the island were under American control. His remarks came just hours before the Danish and Greenlandic ministers arrived in Washington for urgent talks with Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Vice President JD Vance, as Denmark simultaneously announced from Copenhagen that it would strengthen its military presence in Greenland with immediate effect. France24 International Affairs Editor Angela Diffley tells us more.
items.content: The foreign ministers of Denmark and Greenland are meeting at the White House today after President Donald Trump once again reiterated his desire for the United States to control Greenland, the world’s largest island. In a post on Truth Social earlier today, Trump said that anything short of Greenland being “in the hands” of the US was “unacceptable,” adding that NATO would become “more effective” if the island were under American control. His remarks came just hours before the Danish and Greenlandic ministers arrived in Washington for urgent talks with Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Vice President JD Vance, as Denmark simultaneously announced from Copenhagen that it would strengthen its military presence in Greenland with immediate effect. France24 International Affairs Editor Angela Diffley tells us more.

items.title: Trump live: Denmark and Greenland face JD Vance in White House meeting

items.content: Danish and Greenlandic diplomats attended talks on Greenland with US Vice President JD Vance.

items.title: Trump administration ends temporary protected status for Somalis in US
items.standfirst: Critics condemn ‘bigoted attack’ as Trump bids to revoke citizenship of naturalized immigrants convicted of fraud The Trump administration is terminating temporary protected status (TPS) for Somalis living in the United States, giving hundreds of people two months to leave the country or face deportation.The homeland security secretary, Kristi Noem, said in a statement that conditions in the east African country had improved sufficiently and that Somalis no longer qualified for the designation under federal law. Continue reading...

Going forward, the only way to access the feature will be through a monthly subscription. The change represents a major break from how Tesla has…

items.title: Tesla Driver-Assist System FSD Will Switch to Subscription-Only, Musk Says
items.standfirst: Tesla Inc. will stop selling the assistance system it calls Full Self-Driving for a one-time fee and transition entirely to a monthly subscription model, according to Elon Musk.
items.content: Tesla Inc. will stop selling the assistance system it calls Full Self-Driving for a one-time fee and transition entirely to a monthly subscription model, according to Elon Musk.

clusters.title: France's government survives two no-confidence votes over Mercosur deal
clusters.neutral_headline: France's government survives two no-confidence votes over Mercosur deal

items.title: France's government survives two no-confidence votes over Mercosur deal
items.standfirst: The French government on Wednesday survived two no-confidence votes filed by the hard left and far right parties, who accused it of not doing enough to stop the EU-Mercosur trade deal after its approval last week. French farmers say the deal threatens local ​agriculture by creating unfair competition with cheaper South American imports.
items.content: The French government on Wednesday survived two no-confidence votes filed by the hard left and far right parties, who accused it of not doing enough to stop the EU-Mercosur trade deal after its approval last week. French farmers say the deal threatens local ​agriculture by creating unfair competition with cheaper South American imports.

items.title: Economic conflicts are world’s greatest risk, WEF survey suggests
items.standfirst: Extreme weather events and biodiversity loss identified as the biggest global threats over a 10-year timeframeEconomic conflicts between major powers are the greatest risk facing the world over the next two years, according to experts polled ahead of next week’s Davos summit.Among 1,300 business leaders, academics and civil society figures surveyed by the World Economic Forum (WEF), “geoeconomic confrontation” was identified as the most pressing threat. Continue reading...

items.title: Arrests after nine newborn babies die at the same hospital in early January
